questions.text:
A young woman took over the counter medicines for weight loss presented with fat malabsorption and bleeding tendencies and easy bruising. 
Which of the following is probable vitamin deficiency ?
A patient on anti-tuberculosis drugs for last 3 months  present with bilateral tingling sensations and mood changes. Probable vitamin deficiency
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

• Drugs causing B6 deficiencies 

• B6 def : isoniazid , penicillamine , antiepileptics, levodopa,OCP (folic acid, vitamins B2, B6, B12, vitamin C and E and the minerals magnesium, selenium and zinc)

• INH induces a state of functional pyridoxine deficiency by at least two mechanisms.

•  First, INH metabolites directly attach to and inactivate pyridoxine species. Second, INH inhibits the enzyme pyridoxine phosphokinase; this enzyme is necessary to activate pyridoxine to pyridoxal 5' phosphate, the cofactor in many "pyridoxine-dependent" reactions. 

• Functional pyridoxine deficiency is the likely mechanism of INH-induced peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: Cancer cells use Warburg effect, because
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• Unlike normal cells that produce energy mainly by mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation, cancer cells catabolize glucose into lactate under aerobic (oxygen present) conditions (hence the name aerobic glycolysis or “Warburg Effect”  ).

•  Emerging hallmark of cancer but not unique, also seen in rapidly proliferating cells like embryo and lymphocytes during immune response. 

Though aerobic glycolysis is major source of energy, oxidative phosphorylation is still operational at low level.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has a history of biting his lips and fingers. On evaluation, you notice lip lacerations, missing sections of his fingers, and developmental delay. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase

The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine- guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) involved in the purine salvage pathway

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to defect in the biogenesis of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Peroxisomes

Zellweger syndrome is due to a defect in the biogenesis of peroxisomes.

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long- chain fatty acids, defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with diarrhoea and pellagra-like photosensitive skin  eruptions for the last 5 years. Her vital examinations are normal. Urine analysis reveals an increase in the amino acid levels but normal levels of 5-hydroxyindole acetic acid (5-HIAA). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hartnup disease

The above clinical history of a 16-year-old child presenting with diarrhoea and pellagra-like photosensitive skin eruptions with urine analysis showing an increase in the amino acid levels and normal 5-HIAA levels is suggestive of Hartnup disease.

Amino acids are reabsorbed in the kidneys in the proximal convoluted tubule. Aminoaciduria points towards a pathology.

questions.text: An infant demonstrates lethargy, vomiting, and convulsions after a few sessions of breastfeeding. The patient was diagnosed with hyperammonaemia type-1. Which of the following enzyme is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I

The enzyme defective in hyperammonaemia type-1 is carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).

CPS I catalyses the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle and is present in the mitochondria. This reaction uses NH3 and CO2 as substrates to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate. It is a mitochondrial enzyme. Its defect leads to hyperammonaemia type 1.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular analysis method is used to detect monkeypox virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Real time PCR

Real-time PCR is used to detect monkeypox virus which contains enveloped double-stranded DNA.

Real-time PCR helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presented with diarrhoea for a few weeks. His family members report observing abnormal behaviour that they had not noticed earlier. Recently, he has developed a rash around his neck, as shown below. This rash flares up when exposed to sunlight.

Which of the following supplements is most likely to benefit the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nicotinamide

The above clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhoea, abnormal behaviour (probably dementia) and rash around his neck (casal’s neck) points to a diagnosis of pellagra which is secondary to nicotinamide/ niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Hence this patient will benefit from nicotinamide supplements.
Niacin deficiency is mostly seen among people eating corn/maize-based diets, which are low in niacin and tryptophan. Excess leucine in jowar and maize disrupts the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

questions.text: A 54-year-old chronic alcoholic patient presents with altered sensorium and confusion. He also complains of weakness in both lower limbs and occasional tingling in his legs. His staple diet includes white polished rice. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Beri- Beri

The given clinical scenario of a 54-year-old chronic alcoholic, who consumes polished rice as a staple diet, and presents with altered sensorium and tingling sensation (neuritis), points to the diagnosis of Beri-Beri.

The vitamin deficiency associated with this condition is thiamine (vitamin B1). It is commonly seen in people who consume polished rice-based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following post-translational modifications (PTM) is associated with the synthesis of haemoglobin, collagen and immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Subunit aggregation

Haemoglobin, collagen, and immunoglobin are proteins that are synthesized as subunits and undergo subunit aggregation during post-translational modifications (PTM).

Adult haemoglobin is synthesized separately as 2 alpha chains and 2 beta chains and then aggregated together to form quaternary structure.
Collagen is synthesized as pre-procollagen inside cells and released as tropocollagen which aggregates into collagen fibrils through covalent bonds.
Immunoglobulins are components of the immune system and are divided into 5 classes. However, each Immunoglobulin has two heavy chains and two light chains synthesized separately and then aggregated.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely?
Which of the following processes is mediated by CRISPR CAS-9 technology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gene editing

CRISPR CAS-9 technology mediates the process of gene editing.

CRISPR is Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats

- CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material. 

- CRISPRS are transcribed into an RNA sequence that directs the Cas9 to a sequence, leading to its cleavage. 

- Gene editing uses an artificial guide RNA that binds Cas9 and is complementary to a DNA sequence of interest and Cas9 induces the break of double-stranded DNA.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presented with failure to thrive and delayed milestones. On examination, he had elevated transaminases and mild hypotonia without any organomegaly. Ophthalmological examination showed a cherry red spot in the macula. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tay-Sachs disease

The above clinical scenario of an infant with failure to thrive & delayed milestones, elevated transaminases, and cherry red spot on the macula without organomegaly points to a diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.

Tay Sach disease is an autosomal recessive disease. It occurs due to a deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. It presents with progressive neurodegeneration, foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages), a “cherry-red” spot on the macula, and developmental delay but does not have hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: Which is of the following enzymes is responsible for the respiratory burst in neutrophils?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

NADPH oxidase

The deficiency of NADPH oxidase is responsible for the respiratory burst in neutrophils.

NADPH +202 --- > NADP+ +202- + 2H+

NADPH oxidase in the inflammatory cells (neutrophils, eosinophils, monocytes, and macrophages) produces superoxide anion by reducing oxygen by a process of respiratory burst during phagocytosis.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite. It is a folic acid analogue that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). Methotrexate and its polyglutamate also inhibit the enzymes involved in de novo purine and thymidylate synthesis.

choices.text: Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio leads to hypoglycaemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room by his relatives in a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness. His spot blood glucose level was 45 mg/dL. Yesterday, the patient went to the gym directly after work, following which he attended a party where he only consumed alcoholic beverages and skipped his meals. Which of the following is the likely cause of hypoglycaemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alcohol inhibits gluconeogenesis

The given clinical scenario of a patient who had a history of alcohol intake presenting with hypoglycaemia and a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness is suggestive of alcohol (ethanol) intoxication that inhibits the process of gluconeogenesis.
